One key use of exponential models is in the growth of populations. In the Geogebra applet below, try changing the parameters in the exponential function to model the total population in Ethiopia.




It is not that straight-forward! One thing to consider is what the horizontal asymptote could be.

title: 2 Exponentials & Logs
text:
Remember that graphs can be transformed in four basic ways:

Translated vertically
Translated horizontally
Stretched vertically
Stretched horizontally

Let us consider the graph of any old function \(y = f(x)\). Play around with the GeoGebra graphs below by changing the values of \(a, b, c, d\):




From this you can see the following:

\(y = a\cdot{}f(x)\) results in a vertical stretch by a factor of \(a\).
\(y = f(b\cdot{}x)\) results in a horizontal stretch by a factor of \(\frac{1}{b}\).
\(y = f(x+c)\) results in a horizontal translation by \(-c\) units.
\(y = f(x)+d\) results in a vertical translating by \(d\) units.

Adding a parameter translates; multiplying by a parameter stretches.






Warning



Transforming the \(x\) value in the expression of \(f(x)\) results in a horizontal stretch or translation in the opposite way than you might think (by \(\frac{1}{b}\) and \(-c\)). It‚Äôs always worth double checking you have this the right way around!




Recall that \(y = e^x\) is the standard exponential graph where \(e\) is the Euler‚Äôs number.





Every other exponential graph can be expressed as a transformation of this graph, with \(y = e^{b(x-c)}+d\) acting as a ‚Äògeneral form‚Äô.









Let us shift it to the right: \(y = e^{x-2}\).







Move it up - and with it the horizontal asymptote too: \(y = e^x + 1\).









Flip it around the \(y\)-axis: \(y=e^{-x}\).







And a combination of a few of these: \(y = -e^{2x}+4\).





In workshops we‚Äôll explore how some of these ideas (exponentials and logs both) can be used practically in modelling real world concepts.

title: Exponentials & Logs
text:
We have talked about how exponentials can model growth, but in our day to day we don‚Äôt always encounter growth in this continuous way as a curve. Rather, we encounter it in a discrete way as a sequence.


Say I set myself a New Years resolution of reading more. At the moment I read about 3 pages per night, but I have the idea to increase this by two pages every day in January. On the January 1st I‚Äôll read 5 pages, on Jan 2nd read 7 pages, on Jan 3rd read 9 pages, and so on.
The number of pages I will is a sequence: [ 5, 7, 9, . ] The (n^{}) term in a sequence is denoted (a_n), so here (a_1 = 5), (a_2 = 7), etc. By observation we might be able to see that on the (n^{}) day I will have read (3+2n) pages, so here (a_n = 3+2n).
This means that we can work out a given term in the sequence without calculating all the intermediate terms. For example, on January 31st I‚Äôll read (a_{31} = 3 + 2 = 65) pages.
In general, We define the (n^{}) term of an arithmetic sequence as (a_n = a_0 + nd), where (a_0) is our starting value and (d) is the difference we move by each term. So in the previous example, (a_0 = 3) and (d = 2).
Suppose now I want to find how many pages (S) I will read in January total. This would be the [ S = a_1 + a_2 + + a_{31}. ] We could compute this by hand, but there exists a handy formula [ S_n = a_1 + a_2 + + a_{n} = . ] This sum is called an arithmetic series and you may also see this sum denoted using ‚Äòsigma‚Äô notation [ S_n = {m=1}^{n} a_m = . ] For my reading goal, that means [ S{31} = _{n=1}^{31}(3+2n) = = = 1085. ] That‚Äôs almost the same number of pages as War and Peace, so probably not realistic as resolutions go!



Another context where growth comes up is in savings or interest. Say I put (50) in a savings account with 2% annual interest. That is, at the end of the year 2% of the total balance is added extra by the bank.
At the end of the first year, it will contain (50 + 2%50 = 50 + 1 = 51). Next year though, (2%) of my balance isn‚Äôt (1) any more, it‚Äôs (2%51 = 1.02).
By remembering that increasing by (2%) is the same as multiply by (1 + = 1.02), we can put To put it back in the language of sequences as \[\begin{align*}
  a_0 &= \text{¬£}50 \\
  a_1 &= \text{¬£}50 \times 1.02 \\
  a_2 &= (\text{¬£}50 \times 1.02) \times 1.02 \\
  a_3 &= ((\text{¬£}50 \times 1.02) \times 1.02) \times 1.02 \\
\end{align*}\] or, simplifying using powers, (a_n = ^n). That means in thirty five years my savings pot will be a whole [ a_{35} = 50^{35} = 99.99448. ] Well, (99.99) isn‚Äôt nothing, but it‚Äôs certainly not a retirement fund.
In general, We define the (n^{}) term of an geometric sequence as (a_n = a_0 r^n), where (a_0) is our starting value and (r) is the common ratio we increase by each term. So in the previous example, (a_0 = 50) and (r = 1.02). Similar to before, we can compute the sum of these terms - the geometric series - as [ S_n = a_1 + a_2 + + a_{n} = . ] This formula doesn‚Äôt hold when (r = 1) since it would require dividing by zero, though in that case the value of (S_n) can be worked out directly from its definition.

title: 6 Probability
text:
Probability and statistics are closely related. When we analyse data, we need to ask: is this data due to chance alone or is there some underlying pattern? Probability is the study of chance. Probability assigns a number between (0) and (1) to how likely an event is to happen. A probability of (0) means that the event is impossible; a probability of (1) means the event is certain to happen. The higher the probability, the more likely the event is to happen. A probability of (0.5) means that an event is just as likely to happen as it is to not happen (‚Äú50/50 chance‚Äù, ‚Äúeven chance‚Äù).




The ‚Äúprobability of event (A)‚Äù is usually expressed as (P(A)). The probability of landing on Heads if you toss a coin could therefore be expressed as (P(H)) where (H) stands for the number of heads.

The values for probability lie between 0 and 1. They can be expressed as


a fraction, for instance (),


a decimal number, for instance 0.5,


a percentage, for instance 50%,


a chance, for instance: 1 in 2 chance,


a ratio: 1:1.


These equivalent expressions are often used interchangeably and can be used for any probability we wish to represent. For example, consider the event of throwing a five on a fair die. The probability of this is( ) which we can express this as:


a fraction: ( ),


a decimal number: 0.167 (rounded to three significant figures),


a percentage: approximately 16.7% (rounded to three significant figures),


a chance: a 1 in 6 chance or


a ratio: 1:5 (out of 6 outcomes we expect for 1 successful outcome and 5 unsuccessful outcomes).


In this course, we usually express probabilities either as an exact value, usually in fraction form, or as a decimal number, rounded either using significant figures or decimal places.

To calculate the theoretical probability of an event, we need to know the sample space of an experiment.
The sample space is the set of all possible outcomes of an experiment. For example, the sample space for when we roll a die (dice) is the set of the six possible outcomes {1,2,3,4,5,6}. In this case, all these outcomes are equally likely.


When each outcome of an experiment is equally likely, the probability of an event occurring can be calculated by dividing the number of favourable outcomes contained within the event by the total number of outcomes of the experiment.

Work out the probability of:



rolling a 4 and



work out the probability of rolling a number larger than 3.




Solution to a)
There are 4 outcomes in the sample space {1,2,3,4,5,6}. The event we wish to find is rolling a four, which is just one of six possible outcomes. So the probability of rolling a six, is 1 divided by 6, or ( ). Solution to b)
To find the probability of rolling a number larger than 3 consider the number of outcomes that ‚Äúsatisfy‚Äù this requirement. The three outcomes are: rolling a (4), rolling a (5) or rolling a (6). There are still (6) possible outcomes in total and the probability of each is (), so the probability of rolling a number larger than (3) is given by (), which equals ( ).

Now imagine rolling two dice and considering what the possible outcomes are. You could roll a 2 and a 5, or a 5 and a 2. Or two times a 5. You can picture the sample space as a table:



Note that the outcomes (2,3) and (3,2) are not the same. We will come back to this example.

Some probabilities like the ones we just looked at can be understood logically, using theory. In other cases, we cannot figure out the probability of an event using logic alone. For example, if we wanted to know the probability that a woman from a particular population will be between 1.65 and 1.66 metres tall, we need to collect data, i.e.¬†measure the heights of a large number of women in that population to see how many are between 1.65 and 1.66 metres tall, and use this to estimate the probability for the whole population. We call such a probability an experimental probability.
Sometimes, instead of an actual experiment, we can use computer simulations.
Not to put you off but here is Sir David Spiegelhalter‚Äôs take on the understanding of probability:



https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nuSqWRuz-mU

title: 6 Probability
text:
There are some more advanced concepts in probability that we need to cover, but before we can get to those we should probably take a quick detour to properly cover set notation. If this is a concept you‚Äôve seen before, feel free to skip forwards!


Sets are mathematical objects that are, simply put, collections of elements. The are written with curly brackets. They are similar to lists, but lists are ordered and allow for repetition.






Examples




Set of objects on the table: {keys, coffee cup, pen, ‚Ä¶}
Set of people in a room: {Joumana, Julie, Alistair, Yotam}
Set of numbers strictly between one and nine: {x | 1 < x < 9}



The concept of a sample space in probability has an equivalent for sets more generally.






Definition



The universal set is the set of all objects and depends on the context. The universal set of all socks in the world, or the universal set of all students in the course.





Sets on their own are mathematically interesting, and they can quite quickly lead to complicated ideas.[^You might have heard of Russell‚Äôs paradox, the set of sets that contain themselves. However of more interest is how they interact with each other.






Definiion




The union (denoted \(\cup\)) of two sets is the set of elements that are in either set.
The intersection (denoted \(\cap\)) of two sets is the set of elements that are in both sets.
The difference (denoted \(\backslash\)) of two sets is the set of elements that are in one set by not the other.



This is a way of abstractly defining familiar ideas.






Example A



Say \(A\) is the set of odd numbers between 10 and 20: {11,13,15,17,19}.3. Define \(B\) as the prime numbers between 0 and 15: {2,3,5,7,11,13}. The union of these two sets is \(A\cup B\) = {2,3,5,7,11,13,17,19}. The intersection of the two sets is: \(A\cap B\) = {11,13}.


These ideas aren‚Äôt just limited to numbers thought!






Example B



Consider the set of objects on the table, {keys, coffee cup, pen, calculator}, and the set of belongings I need to take with me: {keys, pen, wallet}.
The union of the two sets is {keys, coffee cup, pen, calculator, wallet}, while the intersection is {keys, pen}. The difference between the objects on the table and those I need to take with me is {wallet} - I wonder where I left it?





The place sets come up most frequently is in Venn diagrams.



xkcd.com/773/


A Venn diagram is a diagram style that shows the relation between sets, and was invented by English mathematician and logician John Venn in the 1880s. As the diagrams can be used to represent sets we can use them to represent probabilities for combinations of different events. The circles each represent one set. There can be any number of sets[^Though if we want circles, that limits us to three! Beyond that we have to introduce ellipses, sausages, and other squiggly constructs.]. The rectangle around them is the universal set, denoted \(\mathfrak{U}\).






Example



A survey was done on first year students on what they felt made them like some animals more than others. \(42\)% of students responded saying they favoured an animal that was fluffy, while \(28\)% of students responded saying they favoured an animal that had big teeth. \(4\)% of students responded saying they favoured an animal with both of these characteristics.
We can use these data to estimate the probability that a student will favour an animal that is fluffy OR has big teeth, or is fluffy AND has big teeth. Below we see a Venn diagram of the probabilities that a student‚Äôs favourite animal will be fluffy, have big teeth, or be fluffy and have big teeth.





From this diagram you can see for instance that although \(28\%\) of students seem to prefer animals with big teeth, \(24\%\) students preferred them to have big teeth but NOT be fluffy.


With this squared away, we can return to probability proper and better understand some of its more complicated concepts.

title: 6 Probability
text:
Probability is governed by laws which allow us to understand more complicated questions of chance. If we have more than one event, we need to start thinking about how to combine the events and their probabilities.


In most probability frameworks, whether an event happens is binary: it either happens or it doesn‚Äôt happen. From this, we get a probability relation.






Compliment Rule



For an event \(A\), since \(\mathbb{P}(A) + \mathbb{P}(\text{not}~A) = 1\), \[
  \mathbb{P}(\text{not}~A) = 1 - \mathbb{P}(A),
\] where \(\text{not}~A\) is sometimes shortened to \(A'\), \(\overline{A}\), or \(A^{\text{c}}\).








Example



Suppose that we roll a six-sided die. The universal set is the set of all possible outcomes: $ ={1,2,3,4,5,6} $. Let \(A\) be the event of rolling a number greater than \(2\).
The event \(A'\) is the event that we roll a number that is not greater than \(2\) (i.e. rolling a \(1\) or a \(2\)), so: \[
  \mathbb{P}(A') = \mathbb{P}(\text{not greater than}~2) = \frac{2}{6}.
\]





Suppose we have two events called \(A\) and \(B\). The probabilities for ‚Äú\(A\) and \(B\)‚Äù happening and ‚Äúeither \(A\) or \(B\) happening are related.






Addition Law



\[
  \mathbb{P}(A\cup B) = \mathbb{P}(A) + \mathbb{P}(B) - \mathbb{P}(A \cap B).
\]








Example



Suppose that we roll a six-sided die. The universal set is the set of all possible outcomes: \(\mathfrak{U} = {1,2,3,4,5,6}\). Let \(A\) be the event of rolling a number greater than \(2\), and \(B\) rolling an even number.
The event \(A \cap B\) is therefore the event that we roll a number that is both even and greater than \(2\) (i.e.¬†rolling a \(4\) or a \(6\)). The event \(A \cup B\) is the event that we roll a number that is either greater than \(2\), even or both greater than \(2\) and even (i.e.¬†rolling a \(2, 3, 4, 5\) or \(6\)).
From this: - \(\mathbb{P}(A \cap B) = \mathbb{P}(\text{greater than}~2~\text{and even}) =\frac{2}{6}\) - \(\mathbb{P}(A \cup B) = \mathbb{P}(\text{greater than}~2, \text{even, or both}) = \frac{5}{6}\)





Two events, \(A\) and \(B\), are independent of one another if the probability that one of the events happens is unaffected by whether or not the other one happens. The events are dependent on one another if they are not independent of each other.






Example A



In the experiment of rolling two dice, the outcome of each dice is not influenced by the outcome of the other dice. This means that each outcome is independent from each other.








Example B



The event of me taking my umbrella in the morning is influenced by whether or not it is raining. If it is not raining, the probability that I will take an umbrella is smaller than when it is raining. The two events are therefore not independent, i.e. dependent.


If two events are independent, then we have the following rule.






Multiplication Law



If \(A\) and \(B\) are independent events, \(\mathbb{P}(A\cap B) = \mathbb{P}(A)\mathbb{P}(B)\).





We say that two events are mutually exclusive if they cannot both happen at the same time. For example, we cannot roll both an even and an odd number on a single die, and so the events ‚Äòrolling an odd number‚Äô and ‚Äòrolling an even number‚Äô are mutually exclusive.
We express the mutual exclusion of two events \(A\), \(B\) mathematically as \(\mathbb{P}(A\cap B) = 0\).



We are often interested in the probability that event \(A\) happens given we know some event \(B\) has happened, denoted \(\mathbb{P}(A|B)\).






Conditional Law



The probability of \(A\) happening given \(B\) has happened is \[
  \mathbb{P}(A|B) = \frac{\mathbb{P}(A\cap B)}{\mathbb{P}(B)}.
\]


Conditional probabilities themselves are related through Bayes‚Äô Theorem:






Bayes‚Äô Theorem



The probability of \(A\) happening given \(B\) has happened can be expressed as \[
  \mathbb{P}(A|B) = \frac{\mathbb{P}(B|A)\mathbb{P}(A)}{\mathbb{P}(B)}.
\]


These are algebraic formulae for working with probabilities, though that‚Äôs not the only way to go about it.

title: 6 Probability
text:
Visualisation can be very helpful in understanding probability. We‚Äôve already looked at Venn diagrams so now we‚Äôll turn to trees.



Example of a tree diagram


Tree diagrams, also known as probability trees, are particularly useful when there are several events (not necessarily sequential). They are very useful when investigating dependent probabilities.
Nodes (black circles above) represent outcomes or series of outcomes, while edges (the lines between them) represent steps that move from one outcome to another.






Example



Suppose we a bag containing five counters, of which two are blue and three are red. We randomly choose two counters from the bag, one after the other without replacing the first one in the bag. The possible outcomes are:

choosing either two red counters,
two blue counters, or
one of each.

In order to calculate these probabilities it is useful to draw a probability tree. In this, we should consider the possible outcomes of drawing the first counter; and then the outcomes of drawing the second counter (given the counter we picked in our first draw) and the associated probabilities of these different events. ‚ÄòEvent one‚Äô is drawing the first counter and ‚Äòevent two‚Äô is drawing the second counter.
For this example we obtain the following probability tree, where the circle on the far left-hand side represents the initial state of the experiment; three red counters and two blue counters in the bag.





The two branches of the tree leaving the initial circle represent the two outcomes of the first part of our experiment, where we pick one counter out of the bag. The event ‚Äòpicking a blue counter‚Äô is represented by the top branch, and the probability of this happening, \(\frac{2}{5}\), is shown next to the branch (there are two blue counters out of a total of five counters). The event ‚Äòpicking a red counter‚Äô is represented by the lower branch, and the probability of this happening, \(\frac{3}{5}\), is shown next to this branch. Both branches lead to new circles, which represent the state of the experiment after one counter is drawn from the bag at random.
Each of the two new states have two branches emerging from them. Each branch represents the outcome of having picked either a blue or a red counter on the second turn, and the probability of each outcome is shown next to the branch. The four circles on the far right-hand side of the tree represent the final states of the experiment.
Usually a probability tree is simplified, without such explicit drawings of the practical situation.





Each path through the tree represents a unique outcome of the experiment. Each path corresponds to independent events. Hence, the probability of each outcome along a given path is calculated by multiplying together the probabilities on each branch of the given path.
For instance, the probability of picking two blue counters is \[
  \mathbb{P}(BB) = \frac{2}{5} \times \frac{1}{4} = \frac{1}{10}.
\]
These events (paths) are mutually exclusive, and so the probability of one or the other happening is found by adding the probabilities corresponding to the individual paths. For instance, the probability of picking a red counter on the second go is \[
  \mathbb{P}(\text{red on 2nd go}) = \frac{2}{5} \times \frac{3}{4} + \frac{3}{5} \times \frac{1}{2} =\frac{3}{5}.
\]

title: 6 Probability
text:
Watch this short video (4:31min) from TED- Ed. Be ready to pause the video to solve the riddle when the video asks you to.



https://youtu.be/cpwSGsb-rTs
We will come back to this example in a moment. But first, definitions and vocabulary: A conditional probability is the probability that an event occurs, given that some other event has occurred. For example, it is known that people who smoke are more likely to get lung cancer than those who do not. The probability that an arbitrary person will get lung cancer is quite low, but the probability that a person will get lung cancer, given that they smoke, is much higher. Given an event \(A\) and an event \(B\), we write the probability that \(A\) occurs, given that \(B\) has already happened, as \(P(A | B)\). In the above example, we might write \(A\) for the event that a person gets lung cancer, and \(B\) for the event that that person smokes. Then the probability of a person getting lung cancer, given that they smoke, is \(P(A | B)\). For our Frog Riddle example, event \(A\) is the croak, event \(B\) is that you get the anti-dote to the poison in the mushroom (i.e.¬†you find a female frog). If you walk right, the probability that you find a female frog is \(50\%\). If you walk left, the probability is \(P(B | A) = \frac{2}{3}\).

Conditional probability is important when looking at probabilities of multiple events that are dependent. In the above example, the events \(A\) (a person gets lung cancer) and \(B\) (a person smokes) are dependent on one another, because whether or not someone smokes affects the probability that they get lung cancer.
We can use conditional probabilities to test whether or not two events are dependent: Two events, \(A\) and \(B\), are independent only if \(P(A|B) = P(A)\), and \(P(B|A) = P(B)\). The probability that someone gets lung cancer given that they smoke is greater than the general probability that they will get lung cancer, and so \(P(A|B)\) is not equal to \(P(A)\). Therefore, events \(A\) and \(B\) are dependent on one another. For our Frog riddle example, the two events \(A\) ‚Äúcroak‚Äù and \(B\) ‚Äúone of the two frogs in female‚Äù are clearly not independent because the croak tells us that least one of the two frogs is male. The probability that if you have two frogs at least one of them is female is \(P(B)=\frac{3}{4} =0.75\), but given the croak, \(P(B|A)=\frac{2}{3} \approx 67\%\).

















Example
Suppose a bag contains \(10\) balls, \(6\) red and \(4\) blue. Two balls are chosen (without replacement) at random, one after the other. Consider the two events \(R,\ B\):

\(R\) is event ‚Äúfirst ball chosen is red‚Äô‚Äô \(B\) is event‚Äùsecond ball chosen is blue‚Äô‚Äô

Show that the probability of picking a blue ball second is different to picking a blue ball second given that the first chosen ball was red. Solution Perhaps the easiest way of thinking about and calculating with conditional probabilities is to use a tree diagram. In fact, we have met some conditional probabilities in disguise when we examined tree diagrams in the previous section. Creating a tree diagram for the above situation gives the following:

 Rewriting the branches of this diagram with our above conditional probability notation then gives:

 Thus, we can read off the probability of picking a blue ball second given the first ball was red by looking at the second from top branch of the diagram. Thus, \[ P(B|R) = \frac{4}{9}.\] We can work out the probability of picking a blue ball second by adding up the probability of each branch involving picking a blue ball second, that is \[ P(B) = P(B|R) + P(B|R')= \frac{4}{9} + \frac{3}{9} = \frac{7}{9}.\]



Given two events \(A\) and \(B\) then the conditional probability \(\text{P}(B|A)\) is given by: \[ P(B | A) = \frac{P(A \cap B)}{P(A)} \qquad \text{or, equivalently} \qquad P(A \cap B) = P(B|A)P(A).\]


The top shelf has 3 cans of chicken noodle soup and 2 cans of tomato soup. The bottom shelf contains 4 cans of tomoto soup and 1 can of chicken noodle soup. Because it is easier, we are twice as likely to take a can from the bottom shelf (\(P(bottom)=\frac{2}{3}\)) as we are from the top shelf (\(P(top)=\frac{1}{3}\)).


Suppose we take a can of soup without paying attention to which one it is, what isa) the probability that is chicken noodle? b) the probability that the can was taken from the top shelf, given that it is chicken noodle soup? Solution
Let event \(T\): the can was taken from the top shelf. \(C\): the chosen soup is chicken noodle soup. The probability that the soup is a chicken noodle soup is \(P(C)\). It can be chosen from the top or bottom shelf so \[P(C) = \frac{1}{3} \times \frac{3}{5} +\frac{2}{3} \times \frac{1}{5}  = \frac{5}{15}\] The probability that it was taken from the top shelf, given that it is chicken noodle soup is \(P(T|C)\). Using the formula $ P(T | C) = $ we realise that we have \(P(C)\) but not yet the probability that the soup was chosen form the top shelf AND was chicken noodle \(P(T \cap C)\). \[P(C \cap T) = \frac{1}{3} \times \frac{3}{5}
= \frac{3}{15}\]. Using the above formula for conditional probability \[ P(T | C) = \frac{P(T \cap C)}{P(C)} \] we therefore have \[ P(T | C) = \frac{\frac{3}{15}}{\frac{5}{15}} = \frac35\] So the probability that the mushroom soup came from the top shelf is \(0.6\). Note that the order is important. If we asked, what is the probability that it is chicken noodle soup, given that the can came from the top shelf, the answer would be \[ P(C | T) = \frac{P(T \cap C)}{P(T)} \] we therefore have \[ P(T | C) = \frac{\frac{3}{15}}{\frac{1}{3}} = \frac{9}{15}=\frac35\] which makes sense given that there are three chicken noodle soups out of five on the top shelf.

title: Probability
text:
There are combinations and permutations. They are quite similar with one important difference.
Note that we will not deal with case where repetitions are allowed in this course.

The mathematical function that helps us count how many times a success occurs in a given number of trials is combinations. This is often written as (nCr) or (). This ‚Äún choose r‚Äù can be calculated using the Excel command =COMBIN(n,r). Combinations arise from the simple question: In how many different ways can I select (r) objects out of (n) objects? For instance, if you have seven people, and you want to select two out of these seven, then there are ({7}C{2} = 21) different ways. You can understand this in a visual way also. In each column there are seven squares, two of which are coloured in.
This can be done in 21 different ways.



Let the experiment be that we toss three coins. Let ‚Äúsuccess‚Äù be that any one coin lands on Heads. So each experiment is three Bernoulli trials with (p=). We are interested to know how many of the possible outcomes have two heads. We could make a tree diagram:

 You can see from the tree diagram, that out of the eight possible outcomes, three of them contain exactly two heads. But since, if we were to consider more than just three coins, a tree diagram and counting outcomes would become unmanageable, we use the combination function. We need ‚Äú3 choose 2‚Äù, i.e.¬†({3}C{2} = ). In Excel the function is =COMBIN(3,2) = 3.

There are 6 possible topics that an examiner could chose from. If they need to choose four out of those 6, then we need (_6C_4 = ) = COMBIN(6,4)= 15. So there are 15 different ways that the examiner could chose four topics out of six. You can picture it like this too: ABCDEC. Choose four letters from these six. Here is the list of the fifteen possible choices:





ABCD


ABCE


ABCF


ABDE


ABDF


ABEF


ACDE


ACDF


ACEF


ADEF


BCDE


BCDF


BCEF


BDEF


CDEF






The School of Mathematics has 60 lecturers, and needs to choose 3 of them to teach Introduction to Linear Algebra. How many different lecturing teams are possible? Since we have 60 people to choose from and want to select 3, (n=60) and (r=3). using Excel, we type =COMBIN(60,3) and obtain ({60}C{3} = ) = 34220.

The difference between permutations and combinations is that sometimes, you care about the order that something is chosen.
For instance, if you wanted to choose two colours out of three colours to chose from, Red, Blue, Green.
If you didn‚Äôt care about the order, then there are three ways of choosing the colours:

Red/Blue, Red/Green and Blue/Green.

If however, you care about the order, that would mean that you have six ways of choosing colours:

Red/Blue, Blue/Red, Red/Green, Green/Red, Blue/Green and Green/Red.

Permutations are ‚Äúordered combinations‚Äù.
Imagine a very simple combination lock with only the numbers (1,2,3,4). The combination lock opens when you have the correct three numbers, in the correct order. Therefore, you do not need combinations (despite us calling it a ‚Äúcombination lock‚Äù), you need permutations!
So you have four numbers and need to choose three from these, while caring about the order:





123


124


132


134


142


143




213


214


231


234


241


243




312


314


321


324


341


342




412


413


421


423


431


432





=permut(4,3)(=24). Whereas, there would only have been the following had we not cared about the order - i.e.¬†the combination of three numbers:





123


124


134


234





=COMBIN(4,2)=(4).

When you choose (r) objects from (n) to chose from (be they people, objects or even choices), then you will have


=combin(n,r) to choose from if you do not care about order and do not allow repetition.


=permut(n,r) to choose from if you care about the order and do not allow repetition.


The mathematical formulae, which you do not need to know for this course but which some of you might be familiar with are:


=combin(n,r) (=) to choose from if you do not care about order and do not allow repetition.


=permut(n,r) (=) to choose from if you care about the order and do not allow repetition.




Sample variation is the result of independent trials with unchanging probability where fluctuations are due to many small factors. These fluctuations can be modelled by the normal distribution. This is the essence of the powerful Central Limit Theorem.


For any population, even one not normally distributed, the sample mean (_n) is approximately normally distributed for sufficiently large (n), with (_n N(, ) ).This is called the sampling distribution. (_n) is an unbiased estimator for the population mean ().

In order for the Central Limit Theorem to hold, the sample size is typically considered sufficiently large when (np ) and (n(1-p) ), which is called the success-failure condition.




Suppose that we want to estimate the mean weight of new-born babies. We could take a sample of 20 new-borns, find their mean weight, and use this to estimate the mean weight of all new-born baby. Here, our population parameter is the mean weight of all new-born babies, while the sample parameter is the mean weight of the new-borns in the sample of 20. If we were to repeat the sampling, i.e.¬†take more samples of 20 new-borns, then the sampling distribution is the normal distribution of the mean weight of all possible samples of 20 new-borns.


Suppose that we wish to estimate the probability of rolling a 3 on a die which we suspect to be unfair. We could collect data by rolling the die 100 times and recording whether or not it rolled a 3 each time. Here, our population parameter is the probability of rolling a 3, while the sample parameter is the proportion of times that a 3 is rolled from 100 rolls. The sampling distribution is the normal distribution of the proportion of 3s of all samples of size 100.




Let a random variable (X) have a mean (60) and standard deviation (4). A sample of size (45) is taken from (X). Find the probability that the mean of the sample is less than (59).

Since the sample size is large enough, (n = 45 > 30), we can apply the Central Limit Theorem. [ n N(, ) ] translates to: [ {45} N(60, ) ]
This means that (_{45}) is approximately normally distributed with mean (60) and standard deviation (). Therefore we can calculate the probability using the =NORM.DIST function in Excel:=NORM.DIST(59,60,4/SQRT(45),TRUE) = 0.0468 (3sf). The probability that the mean of a sample is less than 59 is approximately 4.7%.



The content of a certain type of soft drink cans is, on average 328 mL. The content is normally distributed with this mean of 328 mL and a standard deviation of 7.2 mL. Find the probability that:


an individual soft drink can contains less than 325 mL.


a box of 36 cans has average contents less than 325 mL per can.




The random variable is the content of an individual soft drink can. It is normally distributed with mean 328 mL and standard deviation 7.2 mL. Therefore, using =NORM.DIST(325,328,7.2,TRUE) you get (P(X<325) = 0.338 ) (3sf)
The average contents ({36}) of a box of (36) cans is normally distributed with the same mean average (328) mL and with the standard deviation (). Therefore, using =NORM.DIST(325,328,7.2/6,TRUE) you get (P({36} < 325) = 0.00621) (3sf). This means that the probability that a box of 36 cans has an average content of less than 325 ml per can is 0.62% (2sf).

title: Probability
text:
We have studied the normal distribution curve. As mentioned, it was found when errors in measurement were investigated.
In summary, when we take a sample of a population, the difference between its mean and that of the population can be considered an ‚Äúerror in measurement‚Äù. It is unlikely to be exactly the same mean as that of the population, but it‚Äôs unlikely to be totally different from it.



Consider the situation in which a pharmaceutical company wants to test whether a new medicine is effective treatment for a particular disease. (Note that in real life, these tests are a lot more complicated than we describe here but the fundamental ideas are the same.) Let us say that it is known from prior data that 48% of patients with this disease will improve without treatment. Suppose the medicine is now tested on 100 patients improve. Since 60% is an increase of 12% over the percentage of patients who will improve without treatment, can we conclude that the drug increases the improvement rate by 12%? How certain is this result? As we are only taking a sample we need to account for sampling variability when making statements about whether or not the drug improves the condition of the patient. In other words we want to test whether the drug has


no effect on the number of patients or


the drug increases the number of patients who improve.



Farmer Janet grows tomatoes. Last year, she weighed a sample of 50 tomatoes and found that the mean weight was 105.3g with standard deviation 12g. This year, she used a new fertilizer to try to increase the weight of her tomatoes. She took a random sample of 65 tomatoes and found that the mean weight of the sample was 110.6g with standard deviation 13.9g. Can she conclude that the fertilizer increased the weight of her tomatoes?




Think of a hypothesis test like a legal trial where the defendant is considered innocent until proven guilty.


You start with the assumption that the defendant is innocent. That is what we call the ‚Äúnull hypothesis‚Äù.


Decide how strong the evidence has to be in order to overturn the idea of innocence. This is what we call the ‚Äúsignificance level‚Äù.


Evidence is collected and evaluated against the assumption of innocence.


If that evidence goes against the assumption that the defendant is innocent, then the assumption has to be rejected as false. If the evidence does not sufficiently demonstrate that the assumption of innocence can be rejected, then the initial assumption holds.


For the statistical testing the steps are:


Formulate the statistical hypotheses, the null and alternative hypotheses.


Choose a significance level for the test. This is a threshold for making a decision, like the confidence levels we saw previously.


Use data from a sample to calculate a test statistic.


Calculate a p-value for the test statistic. This is the probability of that test statistic occurring under the assumptions of one of the hypotheses.


Make decisions about the hypotheses.


Interpret the decision in the context of the problem.


Note that we would never accept the null hypothesis. If our data is deemed to be consistent with the null hypothesis, then we do not have evidence against the null hypothesis, but this does not mean that we have evidence for it: In a courtroom, failing to find the defendant guilty does not prove that the defendant is innocent, it only proves that there is not enough evidence to find them guilty (the verdict is ‚Äònot guilty‚Äô, rather than ‚Äòinnocent‚Äô).



This part of the course - hypothesis testing - is the A for ‚Äúanalysis‚Äù in the data cycle (PPDAC). A hypothesis (plural hypotheses) is a proposed explanation for a phenomenon.
A statistical hypothesis is a statement about a statistical parameter of some population that we are interested in. In the first example above, the hypothesis would be:


no effect on the number of patients or


the drug increases the number of patients who improve.


but the statistical hypothesis has to use a statistical parameter. We will see how to do this next.



In order to do formulate a statistical hypothesis, we choose a summary statistics of the population that we want to test for. This is called the test statistic. In this course, we always choose the mean. If the observed mean is within the interval of the most unlikely values that we would see if the null hypothesis is true (red area below), then this is evidence against the null hypothesis, and so we reject the null hypothesis in favour of the alternative hypothesis.  If the mean is not within the most likely values (i.e.¬†it is within the most likely values, the blue area) we do not reject the null hypothesis. As an example, say that we want to perform a quality control check on the mean weight of haggis manufactured by a company. We want to test if the mean weight of the haggis is 300g, as stated on the packet. The null hypothesis would be that the mean weight of a haggis is 300g, and our alternative hypothesis that the mean weight of a haggis is not 300g. We take a sample of 100 haggis and weigh them. The observed test statistic is 302g. If, under the assumption that the true mean weight of a haggis is 300g, this observed test statistic lies within the set of ‚Äúmost unlikely‚Äù such test statistic values, then this is evidence against the hypothesis that the mean weight is 300g, and we reject the null hypothesis in favour of the alternative hypothesis.



Any statistical hypothesis test begins with the statement of two hypotheses: A null hypothesis, and an alternative hypothesis. The null hypothesis, (H_0) is a statement about the parameter of interest corresponding to the ‚Äòdefault position‚Äô - the current belief about the parameter - that we test against. For example, suppose that we are interested in testing whether a coin is fair. Our default position is that the coin is fair, and so the null hypothesis would be that the probability of flipping a head is (). In a hypothesis test, we test the null hypothesis against an alternative hypothesis (H_1), which is the alternative to the null hypothesis and suggests that ‚Äúsomething else is going on‚Äù. For example, in the above example, where we wish to test whether or not a coin is fair, the alternative hypothesis would be that the coin is not fair, in other words, that the probability of flipping a head is not equal to (). The null and alternative hypotheses are usually stated together like this:


(H_o): The probability of the coin landing on a head is (0.5).


(H_1): The probability of the coin landing on a head is not equal to (0.5).





A hypothesis test can be either one-tailed or two-tailed. A hypothesis test is one-tailed if the alternative hypothesis states that the population parameter is either greater than or less than some value. The hypothesis test is two-tailed if the alternative hypothesis states that the population parameter is not equal to a particular value. Given the null hypothesis (H_o = _o), the alternative hypothesis could be: (H_1> _o) one-tailed hypothesis (H_1< _o) one-tailed hypothesis (H_1_o) two-tailed hypothesis  as ( _o) could mean ( < _o) or ( > _o) In the previous example in which we were checking the mean score of an exam, it was a two-tailed hypothesis test, because the alternative hypothesis specified that the mean score was not equal to 60%. Farmer Janet hoping that her tomatoes will be heavier due to the use of fertilizer is a one-tailed hypothesis test because the alternative hypothesis specifies that the new weight is larger than the previous year‚Äôs tomatoes. In general, the question we want to answer will determine which type of alternative hypothesis we choose. Deciding which test to conduct is often down to which the analyst or statistician deems most appropriate for the given question being answered. For example, if the haggis company is only interested in whether they are putting too much haggis in each packet (they are not interested nor want to know if they are putting too little haggis in each packet) they may wish to conduct a one-sided test. Alternatively if they are concerned about whether the information on the packet is accurate (or whether their packing machine is correctly allocating haggis to the packets) they may wish to consider a two-sided test. If conducting a two-sided test they can still conclude whether or not too little or too much is being allocated if the null hypothesis is rejected in favour of the alternative hypothesis (we discuss this below).



Exactly what we mean by ‚Äòmost unlikely‚Äô is determined by the significance level of the hypothesis test, which is a percentage that is always specified before performing such a test. A 5% significance level means that we reject the null hypothesis in favour of the alternative hypothesis if our observed test statistic is within the 5% most unlikely possible test statistics if the null hypothesis is true. Similarly, a 1% significance level means that we reject the null hypothesis in favour of the alternative hypothesis if our observed test statistic is within the 1% most unlikely possible test statistics if the null hypothesis is true. The significance level of a hypothesis test could be any percentage, but it is most often between 1% and 10%, and 5% is a very commonly used.



Let us return to the example of the City of Edinburgh Council investigating the speed at which cars drive past a certain point. The council have reason to believe that the mean speed of cars passing the point is greater than the 30 miles per hour speed limit, and would like to test whether or not this is the case.


Define the problem: Are cars on average going past the point going faster than the speed limit? This means that your test statistic is mean speed of cars


Define what level of certainty you need for your conclusion.


Define the hypotheses:



(H_o ) the mean speed of the cars passing the point is 30 miles per hour and


(H_1 ) mean speed of cars passing the points is greater than 30 miles per hour.



Collect data on the speeds of 50 cars passing the point, and calculate the mean of their speeds.


Determine whether or not the mean speed of the sampled cars is high enough to be inconsistent with the assumption that the mean speed is 30 miles per hour.


If it is, then reject the null hypothesis. If it is not, then do not reject the null hypothesis.


Draw a conclusion for the problem stated initially - are the cars on average driving faster than the speed limit?

title: Probability
text:
The Z-test is the simplest hypothesis test and rarely used. But it is a good introduction to hypothesis testing. It can be used to test hypotheses about a population mean () where:


the population is normally distributed


the population standard deviation () or variance (^2) is known.


Remember that if the data of a population is normally distributed with mean () and standard deviation (), then the sample mean ( _n ) is also normally distributed where ( _n ) () (N(, ) ). () is called the standard error. The Z-test can also be used when the population is not normally distributed but the sample size is sufficiently large because of the Central Limit Theorem so that it can be assumed that (_n) is normally distributed). The null hypothesis will be:


(H_o): (= _o ) for a normally distributed population with known standard deviation ().


Let the significance level be called ().

The p-value of a test statistic is the probability of the test statistic or a value smaller/larger/different from it being observed if (H_o) is true. There are three cases:


left one tailed ( p = P(X x_0) )


two tailed ( p = P(X x_0) + P (X x_0) )


right one tailed ( p = P(X x_0) = 1 - P(X x_0) )





If (H_1) is a left one-tailed alternative hypothesis, we use one tail of the normal distribution to calculate the p-value.


If (H_1) is a two-tailed alternative hypothesis, i.e.¬†(H_1: _o ), we use both tails of the distribution to calculate the p-value.
p-value = (2 P(X x) ) when x is greater than the mean or (2 P(X x) ) if x is less than the mean.


If (H_1) is a right one-tailed alternative hypothesis, we use one tail of the normal distribution.


In Excel we use the formulae:


(p= P (X x_0) ) =NORM.DIST(x,mean,standard_err,TRUE).


(p= P (X x_0) + P(X x_0 ) ) =2 x NORM.DIST(x,mean,standard_dev,TRUE).


(p= P (X x_0) = 1 - P(X x_0) )=1-NORM.DIST(x,mean,standard_err,TRUE).

The significance level () sets the certainty of our conclusion. If the statistic measured in the sample falls (usually the mean in our examples) results in a p-value that is smaller than (), this means that probability of observing this value is more unlikely than the significance level we allowed for. This means that (H_o) has to be rejected. In other words, the area of the p-value is smaller than that allowed by ().


The significance level () of a statistical hypothesis test is the largest p-value that would result in rejecting (H_o). Any p-value less than or equal to () results in (H_o) being rejected.






State the null hypothesis (H_o: =_o) and the alternative hypothesis (H_1).


State the significance level ().


Calculate the p-value.


Reject (H_o) if p-value < (), otherwise do not reject (H_o).


Interpret your decision in the context of the problem. Write your conclusion in a sentence.





A new app has been launched. It claims that on average, new users spend 25 minutes on it. From previous, similar apps, it is estimated that the standard deviation in the average time spent on a new app is 3.97 minutes. To verify the claim, the data on 36 new users, randomly selected is collected. It is found that their average time is 23.75 minutes. I.e. ( ) = 23.75 minutes. The level of significance is set to ( ) = 0.05.


(H_0: )


(H_1: < 25)


Calculate the p-value and hence decide whether or not to reject the null hypothesis.

The test statistics we are testing in this case is the population mean. The sample has mean () = 23.75 minutes and the means of the samples (_n) have standard error () minutes. The significance level is ( = )0.05. The p-value can be found by calculating (P(X<25)) for the normal distribution of the sample which is ( N(23.75,) ). p-value =NORM.DIST(23.75,25,3.97/SQRT(36),TRUE)=0.029434609‚Ä¶ Since, 0.029434609 < 0.05, it means that the p-value is less than the significance level (). Translated into English, this means that the probability that we would observe this mean given the null hypothesis is true, is smaller than the given significance level. In other words, it is really unlikely. It is so unlikely that we do not want to assume that it is due to sample variability. Therefore we reject (H_o) in favour of the alternative hypothesis (H_1). This means that although new users might spend 25 minutes on the app on average, the data we have from the sample suggests strongly that this is not the case and we therefore reject the claim.

title: Probability
text:
Last week we covered the Z-test which uses the Normal distribution. We can only use this if the standard deviation of the population is known. This is often not the case, and then we can sometimes use the T-test. When the variance of standard deviation of the population is unknown, we need to use the t-distribution instead of the normal distribution to calculate the p-value.
The steps are as follows:





State the null hypothesis (H_o: =_o ) and the alternative hypothesis (H_1).


State the significance level ().


If not given, calculate the sample mean ({x}) using =AVERAGE() and standard deviation of the sample (s) using =STDEV.S(), and count the sample size (n).


Calculate the observed value of the test statistic (t = ). (NOTE: This is a step we did not have to do for Z-tests)


Calculate the p-value using the t-test function in Excel. =T.TEST(array1,array2,tails,type), =T.TEST.2T(array1,array2,tails,type) or =T.TEST.RT(array1,array2,tails,type).


Reject (H_o) if p-value < (), otherwise accept (H_o).


Interpret your decision in the context of the problem. Write your conclusion in a sentence.






The fat content (in grams) of 30 randomly selected croissants at the 12 triangle bakery off Leith Walk was recorded:




15.6

15.7

16.1


12.9


16.8

14.8

16.1


17.2




For a mean fat content of croissants made at this bakery () conduct a two-tailed t-test of the null hypothesis that the mean is equal to 16 grams on a 10% level of significance.



(H_o: = 16) i.e.¬†the mean fat content is 16 grams


(H_1: ), i.e.¬†the mean fat content is NOT 16 grams (either less or more).



The significance level is ().

Calculate the p-value. The degree of freedom is n-1=30-1=29. Since this is a two-tailed test, we need to either:

Compare the p-value with the confidence level. In this case, the p-value > 0.1 so there is not enough evidence to reject the null hypothesis in favour of the alternative hypothesis.

We therefore cannot conclude that the average fat content is different from 16 grams.




We are often interested in comparing sets of results for the same group of individuals. For example, we might consider:


race times for a class of student at the start and finish of the athletics season


test results for students in a class at the start and end of a semester


weight of sheep at the beginning and end of summer


In this situation we choose a random sample of individuals from the population, then use the data for this group to provide two sets of results for comparison.
The data can therefore be matched in pairs for each individual in the group. Notice that the two sets of results are not independent, since they come from the same sample group. However, the score in each set of results must be independent for the analysis to be meaningful.

That will give you 0.029163177 = 0.029 (2dp). Since the p-value < () we have enough evidence to reject the null hypothesis in favour of the alternative hypothesis. This means that we can conclude with 5% significance that the athletes improved.



We have just seen how two sets of results from a single sample can be compared. We now consider how population means are compared if they come from two different samples.

This means that at a 5% significance level we do not have enough evidence to reject the null hypothesis and therefore we do not have evidence to claim that the Brand B compost will improve the growth of the seedlings more than Brand A.

title: Probability
text:
The hypothesis tests that we learned about so far were all for numerical data. The (^2) (pronounced ‚Äúchi or ki squared‚Äù is the Greek letter ( ) ) test can be used for categorical data. In simple terms, a (^2) test measures how a theoretical model fits observed data. The (^2) test compares the size of differences between the expected results and the observed results, given the size of the sample and the number of variables.
To do a (^2) GOF tests follow these steps:


State the null hypothesis (H_o) and the alternative hypothesis (H_1).


State the significance level ().


Calculate the expected frequencies.


Calculate the p-value using the df = number of categories-1 and use =CHISQ.TEST().


Reject (H_o) if p-value < (), otherwise accept (_o).


Interpret your decision in the context of the problem.


Note that for the (^2) test you do not need to consider whether the test is one tailed or two tailed.



The data points should be frequencies or counts and not percentages or other forms of data.


The categories of the variables should be mutually exclusive. That is, each data point can only belong to one category.


The trials must be independent.


The expected frequencies should be at least five.




Suppose we want to know whether a die is fair or biased. A fair dice would be expected to land, more or less, on each number with the same probability.
Our random variable (X) will be the number thrown. The sample space is therefore {1,2,3,4,5,6}. 
The null Hypothesis (H_o): the probabilities of each outcome is ().
The alternative hypothesis (H_1): At least one of the probabilities is not ().
Let the significance level be set at (). We are testing whether the observed frequencies of outcomes is significantly different from the expected frequencies. The experiment: We toss the die (n = 60) times and note the frequency with which each number occurs.

The GOF test quantifies the difference between the expected values and the observed values. It then quantifies how likely it is that the difference is so large. This is done by calculating the p-value using the (^2) distribution curve.
In practice, we will use Excel in order to do the calculations. The function =CHISQ.TEST() returns the p-value when you input the observed data and expected data and the degrees of freedom which for the GOF test is always (n-1) just like for the student t-distribution.
If the p-value is less than the significance level, it means that the sample data does not match the expected data from the population.
So, continuing on from the above example and using Excel: Input the observed and expected frequencies:

 Then use the command =CHISQ.TEST(actual_range, expected_range) where the ‚Äúactual range‚Äù is the observed frequencies and ‚Äúexpected range‚Äù is the expected frequencies It will return the value p = 0.016931016. Since (0.0169 < 0.05 ), i.e.¬†the p-value is less than the significance level () at (0.05).


This means that the likelihood of the observed frequencies happening is less than 0.05, i.e.¬†very unlikely. This means that the observed frequencies are very unlikely to be generated by a fair die. The null hypothesis should therefore be rejected in favour of the alternative hypothesis that the die is biased.

The (^2) test for independence is used to study whether two variables are independent or dependent.
For example, consider the following data arranged in a contingency table.
